!https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-KGnGpA5xRBI/T01a7KWYhmI/AAAAAAAAC-Q/LHXoKS5WwXU/s1600/Cafe+Martin+-+2+004.JPG!

topics.body:
"@AaronMk":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5520c43d636872434eb40600#post_5520c43d636872434eb40600
Currencies were worth more back then. Things were priced differently.
People were on average paid $10-$20 for a day of work.

Also, instant processed canned foods were still relatively new to the public masses back then when most ate fresh from the field to supermarket foods they prepare at home. Therefore, it was "fancy" for some.
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5520c4b563687245f2da0200#post_5520c4b563687245f2da0200

Values have certainly changed and things have inflated a lot more so than back then.

A friend and I were having a great time too looking at the stuff that in hindsight seems like a weird thing to note on a menu. Like the "mock turtle" from the snips above. There were also menus that made note of carrying canned food but I can't find those right now; I'll have to talk to him when he gets on next.

But I equated that sort of silliness to the sort of fondness my grandma has with the microwave. I don't like to touch our and make up pre-made things from the freezer. Where as she got me some pre-prepared, frozen Philly Cheesesteaks for me; then presented them to me all excited like they're the greatest thing like sliced bread.

They're still in the freezer, untouched alongside the catfish I intend to cook hopefully someday soon.
topics.author: 4fe4bf947f123b175b000001
